page.title: List of Ultras of West Asia

revision.text:
This is a list of all 102 of the [[ultra-prominent peak]]s (with [[topographic prominence]] greater than 1,500 metres) in [[West Asia]]. It includes peaks on the islands of Cyprus and Socotra. It also includes the 10 ultras of the [[Caucasus]] (also listed under [[List of European ultra prominent peaks#Caucasus Mountains|Europe]]) as they are geographically more connected to the mountains of West Asia. Two of these peaks (Mount Aragats and Kapudzhukh Lerr) are on the Asian side of the ridge of the Greater Caucasus, which forms the usual boundary between Europe and Asia, and four more are on the border itself and so in both Europe and Asia.
==List== [[Image:MountArarat.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Mount Ararat]], [[Turkey]]]] [[Image:Turkey.Mount Erciyes01.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Mount Erciyes]], [[Turkey]]]] [[Image:KackarDagi fromNorth hory.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Kaçkar Mountains]], [[Turkey]]]] [[Image:Hermonsnow.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Mount Hermon]],]] [[Image:Kolunchin Zardkuh.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Zard Kuh]], [[Iran]]]] [[Image:قته چرمی کرمانشاه.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Mount Paraw]], [[Iran]]]] [[Image:Alvand 2007.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Alvand]], [[Iran]]]] [[Image:Damavand in winter.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Mount Damavand]], [[Iran]]]] [[Image:Sab dalj1.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Sabalan]], [[Iran]]]] [[Image:BazmanNASA.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Bazman]], [[Iran]]]]

{{short description|A list of notable cookie (biscuit) types}} {{dynamic list|date=February 2014}} This is a '''list of notable [[cookie]]s''' ([[American English]]), also called [[biscuit]]s ([[British English]]). Cookies are typically made with flour, egg, sugar, and some type of [[shortening]] such as butter or cooking oil, baked into a small, flat shape. ==Cookies== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- !Name !Image !Origin !Description |- |[[Aachener Printen]] |[[File:Aachener Printen 0293.jpg|120px]] |Germany ([[Aachen]]) |''Aachener Printen'' are a type of [[Lebkuchen]]. The term is a [[protected designation of origin]] and so all manufacturers can be found in or near Aachen. Printen are made from a variety of ingredients including [[cinnamon]], [[aniseed]], [[clove]], [[cardamom]], [[coriander]], [[allspice]] and also [[ginger]]. |- |[[Abernethy biscuit|Abernethy]] | [[File:Abernethy Biscuits..jpg|120px]] | [[United Kingdom]] ([[Scotland]]) | Invented by Scottish doctor John Abernethy in the 18th century as a digestive improver. An adaptation of the plain captain’s biscuit or [[hardtack]], with the added ingredients of [[sugar]] (for energy), and [[caraway seed]]s. |- |[[Acıbadem kurabiyesi]] |[[File:Acibadem_Kurabiyesi.jpg|120px]] | [[Turkey]] | Traditional Turkish biscuit ("[[kurabiye]]") made of almonds, sugar and egg whites. |- |[[Afghan biscuits]] |[[File:AfghanBiscuit.jpg|120px]] |[[New Zealand]] |Traditional New Zealand biscuit and is made from [[cocoa powder]], butter, flour and [[cornflakes]]. It is then topped with [[chocolate]] [[Icing (food)|icing]] and half a walnut. The origin of both the recipe and name are unknown, but the recipe has appeared in many editions of cookbooks sold in New Zealand. |- |[[Alfajor]] |[[File:AlfajoresTriples.jpg|120px]] |[[South America]] |Basic form consists of two round sweet [[biscuit]]s joined together with [[dulce de leche]] or [[jam]] and covered with [[powdered sugar]]. In most alfajores there are two layers of [[cake]], and a filling in between. |- |[[Almond biscuit]]
''Almond cake, almond cookie'' |[[File:Macau Koi Kei Bakery Almond Biscuits 2.JPG|120px]] |[[Macau]] |Small biscuits with no filling by default, with a crunchy texture, but sometimes crumbling on first bite. When they are sold in different countries, they are usually imported from [[Macau]], where it is one of the most popular specialty products. |- |[[Amaretti di Saronno]] | [[File:Amaretti gobeirne.JPG|120px]] |[[Italy]] ([[Saronno]]) |Italian biscuit similar to macaroons |- |[[Animal cracker]] |[[File:Barnum%27s_animals_examples.JPG|120px]] |United States ([[New York City]]) |Small cracker or cookie baked in a shape of an animal, especially a [[lion]], [[tiger]], [[bear]], or [[elephant]]. |- |[[ANZAC biscuit]] |[[File:ANZAC biscuits.JPG|120px]] |[[Australia]]
[[New Zealand]] |ANZAC Biscuits are a sweet biscuit made using rolled oats, flour, coconut, sugar, butter, golden syrup, bicarbonate of soda and boiling water. Named after the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps ([[ANZAC]]) |- |[[Apas (biscuit)|Apas]] |[[File:07269jfFoods Bitsu-Bitsu Desserts Breads Cuisine of the Philippinesfvf 03.jpg|120px]] |[[Philippines]] |Apas are [[rectangle|oblong]]-shaped biscuits that are topped with sugar. Apas is a [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] term for wafer. They are a popular part of [[Filipino cuisine]]. |- |[[Apple cider cookie]] |[[File:Caramel_stuffed_apple_cider_cookies.jpg|120px]] | |A cookie that is prepared and flavored with [[apple cider]]. |- |Ballokume (from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] ''bal-lokum'') |[[File:BallokumeShqiptare.jpg|120px]] |[[Albania]] ([[Elbasan]]) |Traditional Albanian dessert made of cornflour, butter and vanilla. This dessert is eaten on [[Spring Day]] (14 March). |- |[[Basler Läckerli]]
''Leckerli, Läggerli'' |[[File:Basler Läckerli 01.jpeg|120px]] |Switzerland ([[Basel]]) |Swiss traditional hard [[spice]] [[biscuit]] made of [[honey]], [[almonds]], [[candied peel]], and [[Kirsch]]. The dough is cut into rectangles while it is still hot and a sugar glaze is then added on top. |- |[[Bath Oliver]] |[[File:Bath Oliver Biscuits and Cheese.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom ([[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[England]]) |Hard dry biscuit made from flour, butter, yeast and milk and often eaten with cheese. It was invented by Dr [[William Oliver (physician)|William Oliver]] of [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], around the year of 1750. |- |[[Berger Cookie]] |[[File:BergerCookies.jpg|120px]] |[[Germany]] |Buttery vanilla wafer topped with thick creamy fudge. The recipe is derived from Germany and are an iconic cultural icon of [[Baltimore]]. The recipe was first brought to the US from Germany by George and Henry Berger in 1835. |- |[[Berner Haselnusslebkuchen]] |[[File:Berner Haselnusslebkuchen von Beck Glatz.png|120px]] |Switzerland ([[Bern]]) |Traditional Christmas cake from [[Berne]] in Switzerland, made from ground [[hazelnut]]s. It is sometimes confused with another Bernese speciality, Berner Honiglebkuchen, due to its similar appearance. |- |[[Berner Honiglebkuchen]] |[[File:Berner Honiglebkuchen.jpg|120px]] |Switzerland ([[Bern]]) |Traditional Christmas cookies made with honey. It is distinguished from Berner Haselnusslebkuchen as it often has more elaborate sugar decorations. |- |[[Biscotti]] |[[File:Vin Santo.JPG|120px]] |Italy |In North America, the term refers to a specific type of biscuits, derived from [[Tuscany|Tuscan]] cantucci, a type of hard almond-flavored biscuits traditionally served with [[vin santo]]. |- |[[Biscuit]] | [[File:Digestive biscuits.jpg|120px]] |Unknown |In the US: [[Biscuit (bread)|small soft leavened bread]] ([[scone]])
In the British Commonwealth: a small and hard, often sweet, baked product with different types of decorations, flavors and toppings. ([[cookie]]) |- |[[Biscuit roll]]
''egg roll (鸡蛋卷), love letters, kueh belandah, crispy biscuit roll, crisp biscuit roll or cookie roll'' |[[File:Love Letters (food).jpg|120px]] |Unknown |Biscuit snack commonly found in Asia. It is crunchy and can be easily broken into pieces. Made of wheat flour, butter, egg, sugar and vanilla flavor. The traditional Chinese characters (''蛋卷'') are same for "''egg roll''". |- |[[Bizcochito]]
''biscochito'' |[[File:Fresh_batch_of_Biscochitos,_Albuquerque_NM.jpg|120px]] |United States ([[New Mexico]]) |Crispy [[butter cookie]] flavored with [[anise]] and [[cinnamon]]. It is served during special celebrations, such as wedding receptions, baptisms, and religious holidays. It is usually eaten with morning coffee or milk. |- |[[Black and white cookie]]
''Half-Moon cookie'' |[[File:BandW.jpg|120px]] |United States ([[Utica, New York]]) |The black and white cookie is a soft, sponge cake-like shortbread which is iced on one half with [[vanilla]] [[Fondant icing|fondant]], and on the other half with [[dark chocolate]] fondant. |- |[[Boortsog]]
''boorsoq'', or ''bawyrsak'' |[[File:Boortsog.JPG|120px]] |[[Central Asia]] |Made by deep-frying small pieces of a flattened dough. Often eaten as a dessert, with sugar, butter, or honey. Mongolians sometimes dip boortsog in tea. |- |[[Bourbon biscuit]]
''Bourbon cream'' or ''Bourbon'' |[[File:Cup of tea and bourbon biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom ([[London, England]]) |Sandwich [[biscuit]] consisting of two thin oblong [[dark chocolate]] [[biscuits]] with a chocolate [[Fondant icing|fondant]] filling. The biscuit was introduced in 1910, originally under the name "Creola" by the [[Bermondsey]] biscuit company in London. |- |[[Bredela]]
''Bredele, Bredle or Winachtsbredele'' |[[File:Weihnachtskeks(RobertK).jpg|120px]] |France ([[Alsace]]) |Many varieties can include anisbredela (cake with egg white and aniseed) butterbredle, schwowebredle (orange and cinnamon), spritzbredle, small pain d'épices and spice cakes that are made with sugar rather than honey. |- |[[Butter cookie]] |[[File:Butter cookies.jpg|120px]] |Unknown |Unleavened cookies consisting of butter, flour and sugar. They are often categorized as a "crisp cookie" due to their texture, which is a result of specific quantities of flour and sugar being used. They are often flavored with vanilla, chocolate and coconut. |- |[[Butter pecan]] |[[File:Butter pecan cookies.jpg|120px]] |[[United States]] |Cookie made with roasted pecans, butter, and vanilla flavor |- |[[Caramel shortbread]]
''Millionaire's Shortbread'' |[[File:Millionaire's shortbread.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom ([[Scotland]]) |Rectangular shortbread based biscuit that consists of layers of [[caramel]] and [[chocolate]]. It is commonly known as caramel shortcake, caramel squares, caramel slice, or millionaires' shortbread. |- |[[Carrot cake cookie]] |[[File:Carrot cake cookie sandwhich.jpg|120px]] | |Prepared with ingredients that provide a flavor and texture similar to [[carrot cake]] |- |[[Cat's tongue cookie]]
(''langues de chat'') |[[File:Lengua de gato.JPG|120px]] |Europe |A sweet and crunchy cookie prepared in the shape of a cat's tongue. |- |[[Cavallucci]] |[[File:Cavallucci (24190614015).jpg|120px]] |Italy |Chewy [[anise]] biscuits that contains almonds, candied fruits, coriander, flour and uses Tuscan millefiori honey. The versions of these cookies sold today are a similar version of a pastry which were originally served to servants who worked in the stables of rich Italian aristocrats. |- |[[Charcoal biscuit]] |[[File:Charcoal dog biscuit.JPG|120px]] |United Kingdom (England) |Biscuit based on a powdered willow charcoal or activated carbon mixed with ordinary flour, and made into dough with butter, sugar and eggs. They were originally made to cure stomach trouble and are nowadays enjoyed with cheeses. |- |Chocolate biscuit |[[File:McVitie's chocolate digestive biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |One of several types of biscuit not containing chocolate, such as a [[Digestive biscuit]] or [[Shortbread]], coated with [[chocolate]] on one side or sometimes entirely encased in chocolate. They can be round, rectangular or finger-shaped. These differ from biscuits such as the [[Bourbon biscuit]] and the [[Chocolate chip cookie]] which contain chocolate in the biscuit itself. |- |[[Chocolate chip cookie]] |[[File:Choco chip cookie.jpg|120px]] |United States ([[Whitman, Massachusetts]]) |A drop cookie which features chocolate chips as its distinguishing ingredient, also containing flour, shortening, eggs, and sugar. Variations include recipes with other [[types of chocolate]] or additional ingredients, such as nuts or [[oatmeal]]. |- |[[Chocolate-coated marshmallow treats]]
''Chocolate Teacake'' |[[File:Tunnocksteacake.jpg|120px]] |[[Scotland]] |[[Tunnock's]] teacake is made with a shortbread base topped with marshmallow and coated in chocolate. There are regional variations. |- |[[Christmas cookies]] |[[File:Christmas-cookies.jpg|120px]] |[[The North Pole]] |Sugar biscuits and cookies from various types of doughs. They all have in common that they are shaped and decorated in a way that has something to do with Christmas and its traditions. See also [[Gingerbread]], [[Pfeffernüsse]], [[Springerle]] and [[sugar cookies]]. |- |[[Coconut macaroon]] |[[File:Coconutmacaroons.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Cookies that consist of a paste of egg whites with coconut that is placed on a [[wafer]] and then baked. Its main ingredients are egg whites, sugar and shredded dried coconut. It is closer to a soft cookie than its meringue cousin, and is equally as sweet. |- |[[Cornish fairings]] |[[File:Cornish fairings.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom ([[Cornwall]]) |Soft, chewy biscuits flavored with [[ginger]] |- |[[Coyotas]] |[[File:Coyotas.JPG|120px]] |Mexico |Large flat cookies usually made with brown sugar. |- |[[Cream cracker]] |[[File:Cream crackers with cheese spread.jpg|120px]] |[[Ireland]] |a flat, usually square savoury biscuit often eaten with cheese |- |[[Cuccidati]] |[[File:Cuccidati.JPG|120px]] |[[Sicily]] |Fig-stuffed cookie traditionally served around Christmas time |- |[[Custard cream]] |[[File:Custard cream biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |[[Vanilla]] [[Fondant icing|fondant]] sandwiched between two plain biscuits. |- |[[Digestive biscuit]] |[[File:Digestive biscuits.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Semi-sweet biscuit that typically contains coarse brown wheat flour (which gives it its distinctive texture and flavor), sugar, malt extract, vegetable oil, wholemeal, raising agents and salt. Usually consumed for [[tea (meal)|tea]]. Sometimes sold under the name [[Hovis biscuit]]. |- |[[Dutch letter]] |[[File:Dutch Letters - The Perfect Food (3406778389).jpg|120px]] |[[Netherlands]] |Typically prepared using flour, eggs and butter or puff pastry as its base and filled with almond paste, dusted with sugar and shaped in an "S" or other letter shape. It was introduced into the United States by Dutch immigrants in the mid 19th century. |- |[[Empire biscuit]] |[[File:German biscuit.png|120px]] |United Kingdom |Typical Empire Biscuit has a layer of jam in between two biscuits. The top is covered with white water icing, usually decorated with a glace cherry in the centre. |- |[[Fig roll]] |[[File:Fig-Newtons-Stacked.jpg|120px]] |[[Ancient Egypt]] |A biscuit filled with fig paste that dates back to ancient Egypt. Also known by their trademarked name in the US as "Fig [[Newtons (cookie)|Newtons]]" |- |[[Florentine Biscuit]] |[[File:Florentine biscuits.jpg|120px]] |Italy ([[Florence]]) |Chocolate base topped with candied fruit and nuts. |- |[[Flour kurabiye]] (''Un kurabiyesi'') |[[File:Un kurabiyesi.jpg|120px]] |[[Turkey]] |Butter and flour base topped with an almond or other nuts. |- |[[Fortune cookie]] |[[File:Fortune cookie.jpg|120px]] |United States |Folded sheet sweet cookie with a "fortune" (an [[aphorism]] or a vague [[prophecy]]) written on a paper slip inside. |- |[[Fudge cookie]] |[[File:Vegan oatmeal fudge cookies.jpg|120px]] | |A cookie prepared with [[fudge]] or that has the flavor, consistency or texture of fudge. |- |[[Garibaldi biscuit]] |[[File:Garibaldi biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Currants sandwiched between two oblong biscuits |- |[[Ghorabiye]] |[[File:Ghorabiyeh.JPG|120px]] |[[Iran]] |Made of almond flour, sugar, egg white, vanilla, margarine and pistachio. |- |[[Ghoriba]] |[[File:Ghribia.jpg|120px]] |[[Maghreb]], [[Middle East]] |Made with flour, sugar, butter, and often almonds |- |[[Gingerbread]] |[[File:Gingerbread house.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Commonly a soft dough cookie that is made with [[potassium carbonate]] and/or [[baker's ammonia]] instead of [[yeast]], flavored with [[ginger]] and other ingredients such as nuts and [[succade]]. |- |[[Gingerbread man]] |[[File:Gingerbread men.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Made of gingerbread and shaped like flat male figures. |- |[[Ginger snaps]] |[[File:Freshly baked gingerbread - Christmas 2004.jpg|120px]] |Unknown |Hard twice-baked biscuits that are flavored with powdered ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, and other spices, but predominantly [[ginger]]. They are also known as '''Ginger biscuits''', '''Ginger thins''' or "Ginger Nuts" (a term popular for them in the United Kingdom). They are called "brunkage" in [[Danish language|Danish]] (literally meaning "brown biscuits"), ''pepparkakor'' in [[Swedish language|Swedish]], ''piparkakut'' in [[Finnish language|Finnish]], ''piparkūkas'' in [[Latvian language|Latvian]], ''piparkoogid'' in [[Estonian language|Estonian]] and ''pepperkaker'' in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] (literally, pepper cookies). They may be rectangular or disc-shaped in shape (when they are called "ginger nuts", they are normally circular in shape). |- |[[Hamantash]] |[[File:Homemade hamantaschen.jpg|120px]] |Jewish ([[Ashkenazi]]) |Triangular cookie featured in holiday of [[Purim]]. Shape is associated with [[Haman (Bible)|Haman]], a biblical villain, and his ears or hat. Fruit, cheese, [[poppyseed]] or other sweets are used as a filling. |- |[[Jammie Dodgers]] |[[File:Jamiedodger.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Jam sandwiched between two biscuits, with a heart in the middle. |- |[[Joe Frogger]] |[[File:Joe Froggers.jpg|120px]] | [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | Invented by a former black slave sometime in the late 1700s, but still a popular recipe today. Recipe is a rolled cookie containing molasses, rum, crushed cloves, allspice, and cinnamon. |- |[[Jodenkoek]] |[[File:Jodenkoeken met lineaal voor maat.jpg|120px]] |[[Netherlands]] |Large, flat, round shortbread cookies. |- |[[Jumble (cookie)|Jumble]] |[[File:Buttermilk jumbles.jpg|120px]] |[[Azerbaijan]]{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |Cookie-like pastries whose simple recipe comprises nuts, flour, eggs, and sugar, with vanilla, anise, or caraway seed used for flavoring. |- |[[Kaasstengels]] |[[File:Kastengel.JPG|120px]] |[[Netherlands]] and [[Indonesia]] |In Indonesia, Kaasstengels usually eaten on [[Christmas]] and [[Lebaran]] celebrations. |- |[[Kahk]] | [[File:Ka3ek.JPG|120px]] |[[Egypt]] |Small round cookies filled with ‘agameya (عجمية, a mixture of honey, nuts, and [[ghee]]), [[lokum]], nuts, or dates and dusted with powdered sugar. Traditionally eaten on [[Eid al-Fitr]] and [[Easter]]. |- |[[Khapse]] |[[File:Khapse.JPG|120px]] |[[Tibet]] |Simple cookies made of flour, butter, eggs and sugar that come in various shapes with various decorations. |- |[[Kichel]] |[[File:Kichlach edit0760 (4999713307).jpg|120px]] |[[Israel]] |Jewish and Israeli sweet cracker or cookie commonly made with egg and sugar rolled out flat and cut into large diamond shapes. They are typically eaten with a savory dip or topping. |- |[[Kleicha]] |[[File:Kleicha.jpg|120px]] |[[Iraq]], [[Saudi Arabia]] |National cookie of Iraq that contains a filling of dried fruit (usually dates) and is flavored with [[cardamom]] and sometimes [[rose water]]. |- |[[Koulourakia]] |[[File:Koulourakia.jpg|120px]] |[[Greece]] |Butter-based pastry that is traditionally hand-shaped in a ring form, glazed with egg and sprinkled with [[sesame]]. It is usually made at Easter to be eaten after Holy Saturday. |- |[[Kourabiedes]] |[[File:Kourabiedes platter 2008 01 08.jpg|120px]] |[[Greece]] |Butter cookies (biscuits) that resemble light and airy shortbread, but are typically made with the addition of almonds. They may be flavored with vanilla, [[rose water]], or liquors such as [[metaxa]]. |- |[[Krumiri]] |[[File:Krumiri (4085416867).jpg|120px]] |Italy |Made without water from wheat flour, sugar, butter, eggs and vanilla, in the form of a slightly bent, rough-surfaced cylinder. |- |[[Krumkake]] |[[File:Krumkake2.jpg|120px]] |[[Norway]] |Cookie batter is cooked on a special iron. |- |[[Kue gapit]] |[[File:Kue gapit, 2015-06-16.jpg|120px]] |[[Indonesia]] ([[Cirebon]]) |An Indonesian cookie made from Rice flour, Wheat flour, Chicken egg, Coconut water, salt, sugar, and cinnamon. |- |[[Kue satu]] |[[File:Kue satu 2.JPG|120px]] |[[Indonesia]] |Kue satu or Kue koya is a popular traditional cookie of white-colored sweet [[mung beans]] that is crumbled when being bitten. |- |[[Lady Finger (cookie)]] |[[File:Biskotten-02.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Light, sweet [[sponge cake]]s that are shaped like fingers and are commonly used to prepare desserts such as [[tiramisu]], [[trifle]] and [[Charlotte (cake)|charlotte]]. |- |[[Lebkuchen]] |[[File:Lebkuchenscan.jpg|120px]] |Germany |[[Gingerbread]] with many regional varieties and specialities. |- |[[Lincoln biscuit]] |[[File:Lincoln biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Short dough biscuit and a kind of shortcake biscuits. It has a pattern of dots on the top in concentric circles and was brought to America by British expats. |- |[[Linzer torte]] |[[File:Foto.Linzertorte.JPG|120px]] |[[Austria]] |Jam-covered flat cookie built upon a nutty cinnamon dough and typically covered with a raspberry preserve. Often decorated with a dough lattice and glazed with egg white. |- |[[Ma'amoul]] |[[File:Mamoul biscotti libanesi.jpg|120px]] |[[Arab world]] | Ma'amoul is an ancient Arab filled pastry or cookie made with dates, nuts such as pistachios or walnuts and occasionally almonds, or figs. |- |[[Macaroon]] |[[File:Macaroons.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Consists of a paste of egg whites with other ingredients such as almond, hazelnut and/or coconut that is placed on a [[wafer]] and then baked. |- |[[Macaron]] |[[File:Arc-en-ciel_comestible.jpg|120px]] |France |Not to be confused with macaroons, these colorful, sweet, meringue-based sandwich cookies are often filled with ganache, buttercream or jam. |- |[[Malted milk (biscuit)]] |[[File:Malted Milk biscuit.jpg|120px]] |[[Uttoxeter]], England |First produced by Elkes Biscuits of [[Uttoxeter]] (now owned by [[Fox's Biscuits]]) in 1924. They are named after their [[malt]] flavouring and [[milk]] content. |- |[[Maple leaf cream cookies]] |[[File:Chinese pie.jpg|120px]] |[[Canada]] |Sandwich cookie with a [[maple]]-flavored cream filling. |- |[[Marie biscuit]] |[[File:Galleta María.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Rich cookie made with wheat flour, sugar, vegetable oil and vanilla flavoring. It is usually eaten for [[tea (meal)|tea]] and dunked in tea or coffee. |- |[[Moravian spice cookies]] | |United States |Very thin cookie that contains various spices and molasses. |- |[[Nice biscuit]] |[[File:Nice biscuit.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |[[Coconut]] flavored, this is otherwise a plain biscuit which does not contain cream or jam. |- |[[Nocciolini di Canzo]] |[[File:Nocciolini canzo.jpg|120px]] |[[Lombardy]], [[Italy]] ([[Canzo]]) |Small biscuits similar to dry [[Amaretti di Saronno|Amaretto]], with hazelnut flour. Typical of the town of [[Canzo]]. |- |[[Oat crisps]] |[[File:Gille oat crisps.JPG|120px]] |Unknown |Small, round and flat baked biscuits made from oat, sugar and butter and sometimes flour with additional flavoring such as [[ginger]] and [[syrup]]. |- |[[Oatmeal raisin cookie|Oatmeal raisin]] |[[File:Oatmeal Cookies with orange zest, golden raisins, and chocolate chips.jpg|120px]] |Scotland, United States |Oatmeal cookies are the descendants of oat cakes made by the Scots, going back to the time when the Romans attempted to conquer Scotland. Oat cakes first appeared when they began harvesting oats as far back as 1,000 B.C. It isn't known how or when raisins were added to the mix, but raisins and nuts have been used since the Middle Ages. The first recorded oatmeal raisin cookie recipe was written by Fannie Merritt Farmer in 1896, and billed as a “health food”.{{cite web|url=http://www.foodreference.com/html/a-oatmeal-cookies-907.html|title=Oatmeal Cookies History, Facts and Recipes|author=|date=|website=www.foodreference.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.cookies.com/2010/06/04/|title=cookies.com|author=|date=|website=blog.cookies.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}} |- |[[Oreo]] |[[File:Oreo-Two-Cookies.jpg|120px]] |United States |Brand-name. Consists of two chocolate-flavored round biscuits with a white creme filling in between them. There are now a number of different variations of Oreo, consisting of various flavors of filling and cookie combinations, as well as different sizes {{cite web|url=http://www.snackworks.com/search/product-results.aspx?searchText=Oreo|title=Oreo|publisher=Mondelēz Global LLC|date=|website=Snackworks|accessdate=17 May 2018}} |- |[[Panellets]] |[[File:Panellets (surtido).jpg|120px]] |[[Spain]] |Small cakes or cookies in different shapes, mostly round, made mainly of marzipan ([[almond paste]]). They are often decorated with pine nuts and varnished in egg white. |- |[[Paprenjak]] |[[File:Paprenjak biscuit.jpg|120px]] |[[Croatia]] |Typical Croatian cookie that is known for containing pepper beside sugar syrup or honey, butter, various nuts and other spices. |- |[[Party ring]] |[[File:Nottingham MMB 11 Party Rings.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Commercial circular cookie with a central hole that comes in various colour combinations. Each biscuit is topped with a layer of hard icing with "wiggly" lines in a different colour. |- |[[Peanut butter cookie]] |[[File:Pbcookies2.jpg|120px]] |United States |Features [[peanut butter]] as a main ingredient. |- |[[Petit-Beurre]] |[[File:Petit Beurre LU.JPG|120px]] |[[Nantes]], [[France]] |A type of [[butter cookie]] |- |[[Pfeffernüsse]] |[[File:Pfeffernuesse.jpg|120px]] |Netherlands |Baked traditionally during ''Sinterklaas'', a feast on December 5 |- |[[Pignolo (macaroon)]] |[[File:Panellets.JPG|120px]] |Italy ([[Sicily]]) |Moist, soft and chewy cookie that is of a light golden color, made from almond paste and studded with golden pine nuts (also called ''pignoli''). (At the left in the picture.) |- |[[Piñata cookie]] | | |Multicolored hollow cookies that are filled with various candies. |- |Pinwheel cookies |[[File:Pinwheel cookies.jpg|120px]] | |Refrigerator cookies made by rolling two differently colored doughs |- |[[Polvorón]] |[[File:Polvorón de Estepa.jpg|120px]] |Spain |Very soft shortbread. Crumbles at the first bite |- |[[Pizzelle]] |[[File:Pizzelle.jpg|120px]] |Italy |Waffle or wafer cookies made from flour, eggs, sugar, butter or vegetable oil, and flavoring (often vanilla, anise, or lemon zest) that can be hard and crisp or soft and chewy depending on the ingredients and method of preparation. |- |[[Putri salju]] |[[File:Putri salju.JPG|120px]] |Indonesia |A kind of Indonesian cookie which is crescent-shaped and coated with [[powdered sugar]] covered like snow. In [[Indonesian language]], Putri salju means "snow princess" |- |[[Rainbow cookie]] |[[File:RainbowCookies.jpg|120px]] |United States |Small cake with layers of almond-based sponge cake in different colours, apricot and/or raspberry jam, and a chocolate coating. A variation resembles the Italian flag and is called Italian Flag Cookie. |- |[[Reshteh Khoshkar]] |[[File:Reshteh khoshkar.jpg|120px]] |[[Iran]] |Made of rice, flour, sugar, walnut, cardamom, cinnamon, ginger and spice that is slowly fried in hot oil or fat. |- |[[Ricciarelli]] |[[File:Ricciarelli from Siena-2.jpg|120px]] |Italy ([[Siena]]) |Flavored with ground [[almonds]] and topped with [[icing sugar]]. |- |[[Rich tea]] |[[File:Rich tea.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom |Sweet biscuit whose ingredients generally include wheat flour, sugar, vegetable oil, and malt extract. Due to its consistency it is ideal for being dunked into coffee or tea and is therefore usually consumed with [[tea (meal)|tea]] (see [[Dunking (biscuit)]]. |- |[[Rosette (cookie)|Rosette]] |[[File:Rosette(cookie).JPG|120px]] |[[Scandinavia]] |Thin, deep-fried wafers |- |[[Rum ball]] |[[File:Rumkugeln.jpg|120px]] | |Ground biscuits with rum and binders like chocolate |- |[[Russian tea cake]] |[[File:Russianteacakes.jpg|120px]] |[[Russia]]{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} |[[Jumble (cookie)|Jumble]]-like pastry that generally consists entirely of ground nuts, flour and water or, more commonly, butter. After baking, it is coated in powdered sugar while still hot, then again once the cookie has cooled. |- |[[Sandwich cookie]] |[[File:Bahlsen-Hit-Cookies-Vanilla.jpg|120px]] | |Two hard cookies held together by a soft filling |- |[[Semprong]] |[[File:Kue semprong.jpg|120px]] |[[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[Brunei]], and [[Singapore]] |Semprong, kue semprong, Sapit, Sepit, Kue belanda or Kapit is a traditional wafer snack (Kue or kuih) made by clasping egg batter using an iron mold. |- |[[Shortbread]] |[[File:Shortbreadrounds.jpg|120px]] |United Kingdom ([[Scotland]]) |Very rich unleavened biscuit that is made from one part white sugar, two parts butter, and three parts flour. It is available in different shapes and flavors (e.g. lemon flavor). See [[List of shortbread biscuits and cookies]] for a list of varieties. |- |[[Snickerdoodle]] |[[File:Snickerdoodles1.jpg|120px]] |United States ([[New England]]) |Sugar cookie made with butter or oil, sugar, and flour rolled in cinnamon sugar. Most distinctive feature is the cracked surface that can be crisp or soft depending on preparation. |- |[[Speculaas]] |[[File:Spekulatius four pieces of.jpg|120px]] |Netherlands
Belgium
Germany |Very flat Christmas shortcrust biscuit that contains typical Christmas spices such as cinnamon, nutmeg, white pepper, cardamom, ginger and cloves. |- |[[Springerle]] |[[File:Springerle with typical foot swabian Fuessle.jpg|120px]] |Germany |Very hard [[anise]] cookie made from eggs, flour and sugar with an embossed design that is impressed before baking. It is a typical treat for Christmas. |- |[[Spritzgebäck]] |[[File:Spritzgebäck.jpg|120px]] |Germany |Christmas cookies that consist of a shortcrust pastry that is squirted onto the baking sheet in various shapes and then baked. The finished product is very fragile, crisp, dry and buttery and is sometimes partly coated with chocolate. |- |[[Stroopwafel]] |[[File:Gaufre biscuit.jpg|120px]] |Netherlands |Waffle cookie made from two thin layers of baked batter with a caramel-like syrup filling in the middle. |- |[[Sugar cookie]] |[[File:Sugarcookie.jpg|120px]] |Europe |Very simple cookie made from sugar, flour, butter, eggs, vanilla, and either baking powder or baking soda. They are often glazed with icing and decorated with chocolate or sprinkles and may be themed according to season (e.g. Halloween cookies or Christmas cookies). |- |[[Tahini cookie]] |[[File:Tahini cookies.jpg|120px]] |[[Israel]] |The traditional way to cook tahini cookies is to mix the [[flour]], [[sugar]] and [[butter]] until there is crumbly mixture and then add the raw [[tahini]] and continuing to mix and put the mixture in a round position and add on the cookie almonds or pine nuts, and then it is cooked until it's finished. |- |[[Tareco]] |[[File:Prato-com-tarecos.jpg|120px]] |[[Brazil]] |Little tough disk-shaped biscuit that is made of wheat flour, eggs, and sugar. |- |[[Teiglach]] |[[File:Teiglach,_Traditional_Ashkenazi_Holiday_Dish.jpg|120px]] |[[Lithuania]] |Small, knotted Jewish pastries boiled in a honeyed syrup and often filled with nuts or raisins and topped with [[shredded coconut]]. |- |[[Tirggel]] |[[File:Migros-Tirggel.jpg|120px]] |[[Switzerland]] |Very thin, hard and sweet Christmas biscuits that are made from flour and honey |- |[[Toll House Inn|Toll House Cookie]] |[[File:Toll House Cookies (4335599636).jpg|120px]] |United States ([[Massachusetts]]) |[[Chocolate chip cookie]] from the manufacturer [[Toll House Inn]] |- |[[Toruń gingerbread]] |[[File:PL gingerbread from Torun.jpg|120px]] |[[Poland]] |Polish [[gingerbread]] that can be filled and is often glazed with chocolate or icing depending on variety |- |[[Vanillekipferl]] |[[File:Vanillekipferl und Reisnerkrapferl.jpg|120px]] |[[Austria]] |Small, crescent shaped biscuits that are made from a pastry that contains hazelnut and/or almonds and vanilla sugar and are rolled in vanilla sugar after baking |- |[[Wafer]] |[[File:Karlsbader-Oblate.jpg|120px]] |Unknown |Crisp, often sweet, very thin, flat, and dry biscuit, often used to decorate ice cream. Wafers can be made into cookies with cream flavoring sandwiched between them. Also used in religious celebrations, such as [[Latin liturgical rites|Western Rite]] celebrations of the [[Eucharist]]. |- |[[Wibele]] |[[File:Wibele.jpg|120px]] |Germany |Very small, sweet and dry biscuits whose dough is made from egg white, icing sugar, flour, and vanilla sugar |} ===Unsorted=== * [[Sandies]] ==See also== {{portal|Food|Lists}} * [[List of baked goods]] * [[Cookie sandwich#List of cookie sandwiches|List of cookie sandwiches]] * [[List of candies]] * [[List of crackers]] * [[List of desserts]] * [[List of pastries]] * [[List of shortbread biscuits and cookies]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Lists of prepared foods|state=expanded}} [[Category:Biscuits (British style)|*]] [[Category:Cookies|*]] [[Category:Lists of foods by type|Cookies]] [[Category:World cuisine|Cookies]] [[Category:Dessert-related lists|Cookies]]

revision.text:
{{about|the title of sovereign states|the Canadian indie rock band|The Most Serene Republic}}
'''Most Serene Republic''' (''Serenissima Respublica'' in [[Latin]]) is a title attached to a number of [[Europe]]an states through history. By custom, the appellation "Most Serene" is an indicator of sovereignty (see also [[Serene Highness]] or Most Serene Highness for a sovereign prince); consequently "Most Serene Republic" emphasizes the sovereignty of the republic.
==Modern states== [[San Marino]] is the only modern independent state to use the style. Although officially named simply the "Republic of San Marino",<ref name="cia">{{CIA World Factbook link|sm|San Marino}}</ref> short form "San Marino",<ref name="cia"/> it is unofficially still referred to as the ''Most Serene Republic of San Marino'' ({{lang-it|Serenissima Repubblica di San Marino}}).<ref name="cia"/><ref name="Britannica">{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/521449/San-Marino |title=San Marino |work=Encyclopædia Britannica |year=2012 |accessdate=1 March 2011}}</ref>
==Historical states== *[[Republic of Venice]] ({{lang-en|the Most Serene Republic of Venice}}; {{lang-vec|Serenìsima Repùblica Vèneta}}; {{lang-it|Serenissima Repubblica di Venezia}}), a city-state that existed from 697 to 1797 based in the city of Venice with continuously controlled territory along the eastern Adriatic at its strongest period. "La Serenissima" was also popularly used as a specific reference to the Venetian government or state authorities.<ref>{{cite book|title=Sovereign City: The City-state Through History|last=Parker|first=G.|pages=78|publisher=Reaktion Books Ltd|location=London, UK|year=2004|isbn=9781861892195}}</ref> *[[Republic of Genoa]] ({{lang-en|the Most Serene Republic of Genoa}}; {{lang-it|Serenissima Repubblica di Genova}}), an independent state based in present-day Liguria on the northwestern Italian coast from ca. 1100 to 1805. Long just plain "Republic", the honorific "Most Serene" was only added after the election of the first [[Doge of Genoa]] (1339). Even so, to distinguish their government from its ancient rival to the east, the Genoese rarely used the "Most Serene" designation, opting more frequently for the appellation "Superb Republic" ({{lang-it|La Superba Repubblica}}), a nickname allegedly coined by [[Petrarch]] in 1358.<ref>{{cite book|title=Imperial Ambition in the Early Modern Mediterranean: Genoese Merchants and the Spanish Crown|pages=318|last=Dauverd|first=Céline|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|year=2014|isbn=9781107062368}}</ref> *[[Republic of Lucca]] ({{lang-en|the Most Serene Republic of Lucca}}; {{lang-it|Serenissima Repubblica di Lucca}}), a [[city-state]] that existed from 1119 to 1799 based in the city of [[Lucca]], in northern [[Tuscany]], [[Italy]]. Lucca was the third largest Italian city state (after [[Venice]] and [[Genoa]]) with a republican constitution ("comune") to remain independent over the centuries.<ref>{{cite book|title=Nuova geografia di Ant. Federico Busching|last=Busching|first=Federico|location=Venice, Italy|publisher=Antonio Zatta|year=1777}}</ref> *[[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] ({{lang-en|the Most Serene Republic of Poland}}; {{lang-pl|Najjaśniejsza [[Rzeczpospolita]] Polska}}, {{lang-lat|Serenissima Res Publica Poloniae}}), an [[royal election|elective monarchy]] in Central and Eastern Europe, existing from 1569 until 1795.<ref name="Ferrand">{{cite book |author=Antoine-François-Claude Ferrand|title=Histoire des trois démembremens de la Pologne: pour faire suite à l'histoire de l'Anarchie de Pologne par Rulhière|year=1820|editor= |page=182 |pages= |chapter=Volume 1 | chapterurl = |publisher=Deterville|location=Paris, France|isbn=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j1kPAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|format= |accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Serene Highness]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:History of Europe]] [[Category:Former republics]]

revision.text:
'''Ngola''' was the title for rulers of the [[Ndongo]] kingdom which existed from the 14th to the 17th century in what is now [[Angola]]. The full title was "''Ngola a Kiluanje''", which is often shortened to simply "''Ngola''", hence the name of the modern country.
==See also== *[[Ndongo]] *[[List of Ngolas of Ndongo]] *[[History of Angola]] *[[Ngola (language)]]
[[Category:Matamban and Ndongo monarchs]]
{{Angola-stub}}

revision.text:
{{short description|All-news radio station in Jakarta, Indonesia}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox radio station | name = PM2FGZ | image = Elshinta-90.jpg | image_size = 200px | city = [[Central Jakarta]], [[DKI Jakarta|Special Jakarta Capital Region]] | area = [[Jabodetabek]] (Greater Jakarta), [[Karawang]], [[Serang]], parts of [[Lebak Regency|Lebak]], [[Purwakarta]], and West Bandung [[Regency]] | branding = ''Elshinta News and Talk'' | slogan = Berita Aktual dan Informasi Terkini, 24 Jam Non Stop (English: Actual news and latest information)[https://twitter.com/radioelshinta Elshinta's Twitter] | frequency = 90.0 [[Megahertz|MHz]] | former_frequencies = 1368 [[AM Radio|AM]],[http://wahyusha.blogspot.co.id/2007/12/sebagai-broadcaster.html] 90.05 FM[http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/asiapacific/radio/indonesia_1.shtml] | airdate = 1972, All-news format: 14 February 2000[http://m.elshinta.com/news/136451/2018/02/14/tema-sunda-warnai-hut-elshinta-news-and-talk-ke-18 (Indonesian) Elshinta's 18th anniversary celebration] | format = [[Talk radio]] | class = A | owner = Elshinta Media Network (under [[Salim Group]]) | website = {{URL|elshinta.co.id}} }} '''PM2FGZ''' ([[90.0 FM]], often abbreviated 90 FM), on air name '''Elshinta News and Talk''' or '''Elshinta''', is an all-news radio in Jakarta, Indonesia. == History == In 1972, the station was started under Soejoso Karsono, a musician. Elshinta starts as an [[amateur radio]] named after his daughter Elshinta. At that time, Elshinta Radio plays Hawaiian music. The station's name influenced Karsono's band name, The Elshinta's Hawaiian Seniors. Later in 1976, Elshinta name was dropped from the band's name.[http://historia.id/persona/articles/the-singing-commodore-DLQwv (Indonesian) ''The Singing Commodores'', historia.id] After acquisition by [[Salim Group]], Karsono created Suara Irama Indah (now [[PM2FGG|Jak 101 FM]]), first commercial FM radio in Indonesia. Later on, Elshinta became music radio with a few news insert, due to limitations of news broadcast pre-[[1998 Jakarta Riot|1998]]. Elshinta completely abandoned its music programming in 14 February 2000. Today, Elshinta only broadcasts news and talk programming, except sponsored content and affiliations like [[NHK]] World Service.[https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/resources/brochure/pdf/rj_id.pdf (Indonesian) NHK Radio Brochure] Before 2011, Elshinta was in the same group with [[Indosiar]] TV. In 2011, Indosiar was acquired by Elang Media Teknologi/[[Emtek]], owner of [[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]].[https://economy.okezone.com/read/2011/03/03/278/430888/akhirnya-sctv-akuisisi-indosiar-rp496-54-miliar (Indonesian) SCTV acquisition over Indosiar] Elshinta was also acquired by Emtek, but separated in 2013, creating new entity "Elshinta Media". == Programming == * News and Talk Edisi Pagi (morning show, 5-10am) * News and Talk Edisi Siang (high noon show, 10am-4pm) * News and Talk Edisi Sore (afternoon to evening show, 4pm-9pm) * News and Talk Edisi Malam (night show 9pm-12am) * News and Talk Edisi Dinihari (after midnight show, 12-5am) * Interactive Discussion (11pm-1am, together with News and Talk Malam) * Komisi Anda (late night discussion show, 1-5am together with News and Talk Dinihari) * NHK World Service * [[China Radio International]] (CRI)[https://nasional.kompas.com/read/2010/04/20/14104141/Elshinta.Radio.China.Kerja.Sama (Indonesian) Elshinta partners with CRI] [http://www.elshinta.co.id/onair_program.htm Elshinta Programming] == Network == Elshinta has 8 regional stations that are self-owned. Elshinta regional stations relay Jakarta's broadcast, but sometimes local news session is found in certain stations. Elshinta also has 32 affiliations across the Indonesian [[archipelago]].[http://www.elshinta.co.id/profil.htm] === Self-owned Stations === * 89.3 Elshinta [[Bandung]] (PM3FXH) * 91.0 Elshinta [[Semarang]] (PM4FAH) * 97.6 Elshinta [[Surabaya]] (PM6FKO) * 99.9 Elshinta [[Tegal (city)|Tegal]] (PM4FBF) * 93.2 Elshinta [[Medan]] (PM3FAP) * 99.6 Elshinta [[Bandar Lampung|Lampung]] (PM8FFK, ex-88.5 FM, licensed in [[Tanggamus]] [[Regency]])[http://www.elshinta.co.id/onair_program-jaringan.htm Newest network of Elshinta][https://www.asiawaves.net/indonesia-fm-radio-99.htm] * 103.7 Elshinta Sekayu ([[South Sumatra]]) (PM7FDR) * 96.7 Elshinta [[Palembang]] (PM7FDK) == Media Group == Elshinta has its own media group, consists of Elshinta Magazine, Elshinta.com, TV station in Jakarta [[Elshinta TV]], and Fit Radio. == Influence == Elshinta broadcasts simultaneous news update when a great disaster is happened in Indonesia, especially where the radio network exists. Some people relied to Elshinta for disaster updates, especially before Internet use increased in Indonesia. In Jakarta, Elshinta competes only with [[Radio Republik Indonesia|RRI Pro 3]] 88.8 FM, but its provincial stations have local competitors like [[PM3FHZ|107.5 PRFM]] and [[PM6FJK|Suara Surabaya 100 FM]].
In 2016 Jakarta Attack and 2018 Surabaya Attack, Elshinta broadcast updates and commentaries about that terrorism event. However, Elshinta was warned by the Broadcasting Commission (KPI) due to fake explosion news spreadinghttp://www.kpi.go.id/index.php/id/lihat-sanksi/33159-teguran-tertulis-program-siaran-radio-elshinta in 2016 Jakarta Attack. Elshinta said that they never spread that hoax news. == References == {{reflist}} {{Asia topic|List of radio stations in}} {{Jakarta Radio}} [[Category:Talk radio stations]] [[Category:Radio stations in Indonesia]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1972]] {{Asia-radio-station-stub}}

{{Infobox TV channel | name = Pink Plus | logofile = Pink Plus.svg | logosize = 150px | logoalt = | logo2 = | launch = | closed date = | picture format = [[4:3]] ([[576i]], [[SDTV]]) | share = | share as of = | share source = | network = | owner = | slogan = | country = | language = | broadcast area = | affiliates = | headquarters = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | former names = | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = | timeshift names = | web = | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = [[UBI World TV]] Pink Plus | sat chan 1 = Channel 91 | sat serv 2 = [[UBI World TV]] Pink Extra | sat chan 2 = Channel 92 | cable serv 1 = [[naxoo]] (Switzerland) | cable chan 1 = Channel 306 | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | adsl serv 1 = | adsl chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }}
'''Pink Plus''' is [[RTV Pink]]'s satellite channel.
Headquartered in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], it mostly targets [[Serbian diaspora]]. It can be viewed in [[Europe]], [[South America]], [[North America]] and [[Australia]] & [[New Zealand]] on [[UBI World TV]].
Being Pink's primary satellite channel, half of Pink Plus' lineup consists of programmes from Pink's terrestrial channel while the other half is directly tailored for viewers outside Serbia with shows that are only broadcast on Pink Plus (''Halo Pink'', ''Skandal Plus'', ''Tele kviz'', etc.).
The channel gained some notoriety for the footage of its presenter Sanja Nikolić fainting and losing consciousness on air whilst filming ''Halo Pink''.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4xMmbP4TbuQ Sanja Nikolic of Pink Plus faints on air]</ref> The clip became an instant [[viral video]] during the early 2000s.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rtvpink.com/pinkplus/ Official Website]

{{distinguish|text=Polish radio station [[Radio Maryja]]}} {{Infobox radio station |name = Radio Maria |image = |area = Worldwide |frequency = [[FM broadcasting|FM]], [[AM broadcasting|AM]], [[Shortwave]], [[Cable radio|Cable]],
[[Subsidiary communications authority|SCA/SCMO]], [[Digital Audio Broadcasting|DAB]], [[Digital Radio Mondiale|DRM]], [[DVB-T]],
[[Satellite broadcasting|Satellite]], [[Sirius XM Radio|Sirius XM]],
[[Internet streaming]] |airdate = {{Start date|1987}} |format = [[Catholic radio|Catholic]] |owner = Associazione Radio Maria (The World Family of Radio Maria) |sister_stations = [[Radio Vaticana]] |webcast = [http://www.radiomaria.org/radio-maria-in-the-world-2/ www.radiomaria.org/radio-maria-in-the-world-2/] |website = {{URL|http://www.radiomaria.org/}} }} [[File:World Family of Radio Maria.png|thumb|300px|The World Family of Radio Maria]] [[File:Radio María-Chile.jpg|thumb|Radio Maria emission in [[Chile]].]] '''Radio Maria''' (formally known as '''The World Family of Radio Maria'''; {{lang-es|Radio María}}, {{lang-pt|Rádio Maria}}, {{lang-hr|Radio Marija}}, {{lang-mt|Radju Marija}}, {{lang-lt|Marijos Radijas}}, {{lang-hu|Mária Rádió}}, {{lang-ru|Радио Мария}}, {{lang-uk|Радіо Марія}}, known in Germany as ''Radio Horeb'') is an international [[Roman Catholicism|Catholic]] radio [[broadcasting]] service founded in [[Erba (CO)|Erba]], [[province of Como]], in the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milan|diocese of Milan]], [[Italy]], in 1987. The World Family of Radio Maria was formed in 1998, mainly based on the [[Our Lady of Medjugorje]] apparitions and messages, and today has branches in 55 countries around the world. Its mission includes [[Liturgy]], [[Catechesis]], [[Spirituality]], Spiritual assistance with everyday issues, Information, Music, and Culture. == History == Its first broadcast facility was originally parish operated in [[Erba, Lombardy|Arcellasco d'Erba]] ([[province of Como]], Italy), but was later re-formed as a separate entity outside its home parish as an association of lay people and priests in 1987 as Radio Maria Italia. In less than five years, it grew into a national Catholic radio network throughout Italy. Though not directly connected with the [[Roman Catholic Church]], it was founded as an instrument of the Church, and as a tool for [[evangelism|evangelization]], implementing and adhering to the teachings of the Church. It was inspired by the Marian apparitions at [[Fátima, Portugal]] (and in more recent years in [[Medjugorje]]), pleading for worldwide conversion. As such, Radio Maria is not subsidized or funded by the Roman Catholic Church; instead it is underwritten by listener contributions. In 1994, don M. [[Galbiati]], the principal founder, left Radio Maria and founded Radio Mater, even in Arcellasco d'Erba, as a totally separated entity. Since [[5 September]] of the same year, transmissions started in [[Albavilla]] (yet in province of Como). The [[Liturgy of the Hours]] is diffused in the [[Roman Rite]]. Radio Mater is broadcast via radio in Italy, in Europe via satellite ([[DVB-S]] [[Hot Bird]]), and via Internet ([[Windows Media Player|WMP]]). The World Family of Radio Maria was formed in 1998 out of its subsequent international growth in the 1990s, and following the 1987 speech by [[Pope John Paul II]] in St Peter's Square addressing the need for a new evangelization. Emanuele Ferrario (inspired by the Pope's words to form that new evangelization) is the founder and president of Radio Maria Inc., which has since grown into an association of 40 multilingual broadcast operations in Africa, Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and the Americas. Overall, Radio Maria operates approximately 1,500 terrestrial radio transmitters worldwide. === Radio Maria USA === {{Main|Radio Maria (USA)}} Its [[United States|United States of America]] operations is one of the newest joining the World Family in May 2000 with [[KJMJ]] (AM) in [[Alexandria, Louisiana]] being the originating English-language station, together with a network of several FM and AM repeaters in Louisiana, an AM station in Port Arthur, Texas on 1250 AM ([[KDEI]]), and an FM repeater in Anna, Ohio. An AM repeater in Springfield, Ohio east of Dayton commenced broadcasting in June 2008 with new FM repeaters in Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania coming on the air in June 2009, D'Iberville, Mississippi and Peshtigo, Wisconsin both in May 2010. Spanish-language and Italian-language programming is heard on FM [[subcarrier]] frequencies in [http://mas.radiomaria.us/ Boston], [http://nyi.radiomaria.us/ Chicago], [http://radiomariahouston.com/ Houston], [http://nys.radiomaria.us/ New York City] and [http://nys.radiomaria.us/ Washington, D.C.]. Italian-language programming can also be heard on [https://web.archive.org/web/20100629123340/http://www.radiomarianyi.org/ New York City] FM subcarrier as well as French Canadian and English speaking services on FM subcarriers in [[Toronto]], Ontario. Audiostreaming is available from most of these stations. == World Family of Radio Maria == === Radio stations in Europe === {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! [[Nation]] ! http://www.radiomariahouston.com/ |[[Catholic Church in USA|USA]] |- | {{flag|Venezuela}} | Radio María Venezuela {{Link language|es}} | 1450 AM in Caracas | http://www.radiomaria.org.ve/ | [[Catholic Church in Venezuela|Venezuela]] |} == Programming == Programming mostly consists of traditional Catholic worship music, but some stations also air a mix of traditional and [[Contemporary Catholic music]], along with various talk and teaching programs discussing the Catholic faith, frequent recitals of the Holy Rosary, novenas and Masses. == Facilities == Radio Maria's programming mostly emanates from one centrally located studio or station in a given region or country, and is then re-broadcast (or "simulcast") on a network of repeater transmitters on the AM and FM bands. Some employ the use of a [[subcarrier]], also known as SCA (for "[[Subsidiary Communications Authority]]") facilities of FM stations, requiring the use of a receiver designed to receive SCA signals. Since the emergence of the internet, audiostreaming has been used extensively as a means to help fill-in gaps left by the unavailability of AM or FM frequencies in metropolitan areas already taken up by commercial, public, or other religious broadcasters. Beginning in June 2008, there are now [[shortwave]] transmissions originating from Italy at 26,000 kHz and at 26,010 kHz DRM making it the only (and last) shortwave service originating in Italy besides [[Vatican Radio]].{{cite web | title=Radio Maria: the last and only Short Wave from Italy | date=2008-06-23 | author=Italradio - Osservatorio Radiofonia Internazionale in Lingua Italiana | url=http://portale.italradio.org/portale/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1179&newlang=eng | accessdate= 2011-06-14}} There are presently no commercial satellite radio subscription services (such as [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky Digital]], [[Sirius Satellite Radio|Sirius]] or [[XM Radio|XM]]) of Radio Maria. However its Spanish-language, Italian-language and Polish-language stations may be available in some areas served by the Dish Pronto division of [[Dish Network]], a satellite television subscription service. ==See also== {{Portal|Catholicism|Italy|Media}} *[[Mary, mother of Jesus|Blessed Virgin Mary]] *[[Christian radio]] *[[Contemporary Catholic music]] *[[List of religious radio stations]]
